Award.AbstractNarration:
Set theory is a field of mathematical logic which provides a solid foundation and analysis of the idea of infinity used in mathematics. Among the historically important applications of set theory are independence results, which are theorems which assert that certain statements can neither be proved nor disproved from the axioms of mathematics, or equivalently, that certain statements together with their negations are both consistent with such axioms. As an example, the continuum problem, which was posed by the founder of set theory Georg Cantor, asks how the size of the real number line compares with the infinite cardinalities. This problem was shown to be independent by the work of GÃ¶del and Cohen. In the process, Cohen introduced forcing, which is a powerful technique for creating models of set theory which can be analyzed in terms of the combinatorial properties of partially ordered sets. The goals of the project are to make advances in the theory of forcing, and to prove consistency results in combinatorial set theory.

The main topics of the project are side condition forcing and its application to proving independence results. For several decades, elementary substructures have been an indispensable tool in many combinatorial arguments in set theory. The method of side conditions involves including elementary substructures in the conditions of a forcing poset, in order to ensure cardinal preservation or stronger properties, such as properness and the approximation property. The project will build on previous work of Krueger in the theory of adequate sets, which is a style of side condition forcing which has resulted in a number of advances in the area. For example, adequate sets were used to construct a forcing poset for adding a club subset of the second uncountable cardinal with finite conditions, while preserving CH, solving an open problem of Friedman. We aim to develop general techniques in side condition forcing, and to apply these techniques to solve problems in combinatorial set theory, especially problems related to the square principle, the approachability ideal, forcing axioms, the theory of trees, ideals and filters, and stationary sets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported research in the mathematical subject of set theory. Set theory is a branch of mathematical logic which explores and analyzes the concept of infinite sets as used in mathematics. This subject is of fundamental importance to the foundations of mathematics because it provides a rigorous framework in which the various basic subjects of mathematics can be developed. The specific area of set theory studied in this project is called consistency results and forcing. Forcing is a method for producing models of mathematics in which a variety of properties hold, showing that such properties cannot be disproven in mathematics. This way one can show that certain mathematical questions are in principle unresolvable, since by forcing one can produce two models which answer the question in opposite ways.

The project was very fruitful and resulted in a large number of publications in high quality peer reviewed journals. These publications include solutions to some previously open problems in the subject which were posed by some of the leading researchers in the field. Many of the deepest results obtained introduced innovative new approaches to the method of forcing, including a relatively recent topic called side conditions. These new approaches were necessary because the previously established methods were inadequate for resolving the questions which the research conducted answered.

The grant provided summer support to graduate students, including from underrepresented groups. It also supported summer research experiences with talented undergraduate students. The grant supported travel to a number of conferences and colloquia, including prestigious international conferences such as the set theory workshops at the famous Mathematisches Forschungsinstitut Oberwolfach in Oberwolfach, Germany, and CIRM Luminy in France. Other travel supported by this grant includes trips to Rutgers University, Cornell University, and University of Illinois Chicago, among others.
